questions.question: Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to 3} \frac{x^2 - 9}{x^2 + 2x - 15} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{x^2 - 1}{x^2 + 2x - 3} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to -4} \frac{x^2 + 3x - 4}{x^2 + 5x + 4} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to 5} \frac{x^2 - 25}{x^2 - 3x - 10} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to -2} \frac{x^2 + 4x + 4}{x^2 + 3x + 2} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to 1} \frac{x^2 + x - 2}{x^2 - 1} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to -3} \frac{x^2 + 5x + 6}{x^2 + 2x - 3} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to 2} \frac{x^2 - 4}{x^2 + 5x - 14} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to -1} \frac{x^2 + 3x + 2}{x^2 + 4x + 3} \)
Evaluate \( \lim_{x \to 4} \frac{x^2 - 16}{x^2 - 2x - 8} \)
Which of these is likely to be the value of f(−3.2)?
questions.explanation: At x = -3.2, there appears to be a vertical asymptote or discontinuity where the function is not defined.

questions.question: Which of these is likely to be the value of f(3)?
questions.explanation: At x = 3, the function appears to have a defined value around 2.2 on the y-axis.

questions.question: Which of these is likely to be the value of f(6.5)?
questions.explanation: At x = 6.5, there is likely a point of discontinuity or hole where the function is not defined.

questions.question: Which of these is likely to be the value of f(8.7)?
questions.explanation: At x = 8.7, the function appears to have a defined value around 1.2 on the y-axis.

questions.question: Which of these is likely to be the value of f(1.5)?
questions.explanation: At x = 1.5, there appears to be a vertical asymptote or point where the function is not defined.

questions.question: Which of these is likely to be the value of lim┬(x→-3.2) f(x)?
questions.explanation: As x approaches -3.2 from both sides, the function appears to approach a value around 2.3, even though f(-3.2) is undefined.

questions.question: Which of these is likely to be the value of lim┬(x→1.5) f(x)?
questions.explanation: As x approaches 1.5 from both sides, the function appears to approach a value around 3.5, despite f(1.5) being undefined.

questions.question: Which of these is likely to be the value of lim┬(x→8.7) f(x)?
questions.explanation: As x approaches 8.7, the limit equals the function value, both around 1.2, indicating continuity at this point.

questions.question: Which of these is likely to be the value of lim┬(x→0⁻) f(x)?
questions.explanation: As x approaches 0 from the left side, the function appears to approach a value around 3.5.

questions.question: Conceptual — Why might a limit not exist at a point?
options: The function is not defined at that x-value.
The left-hand and right-hand limits are not equal.
The function increases without bound near that x-value.
Any of the above situations can cause a limit not to exist.
questions.explanation: A limit may not exist if: (1) function undefined at point, (2) left/right limits differ, or (3) unbounded behavior occurs. All are valid reasons.
